reviewText:
I simply got hooked on this game, big time.  This is one of those games that isn't fun, yet it's still entertaining.  Maybe, it's because it's kind of relaxing, just driving a big truck along European highways at night, with nothing to worry about except getting to Point B except offcourse obeying the traffic rules and knowing what your side of the road you are on specially in the UK.
I like also dig the concept of starting out your company from scratch and make it successful.  In addittion, you can pretend travelling through Europe and enjoying the amazing landscapes.
The single and probably the main reason this game is so appealing to me is the fact that I can listen to my own music playlist or watch a youtube clip  and still play it.  I like that in games.  Sometimes, I pause for a while and read news articles online then come back and play.
The graphics are decent, and the gameplay has enough variety to keep you going for a while, with many different European and UK cities.  And the developers are great, offering expansions and DLCs to an already great game.
I would definitely recommend for people who enjoy simulators because this one is pretty good.  I haven't tried the multiplayer mod yet.  I read somewhere that there are only a couple of servers available (US and UK) with very strict gameplay rules.
All in all, it has been a very immersive and interesting experience and I give a score of 8/10.

reviewText:
Let me just give you a short review:

In the beginning it was a joke but when I started playing I found myself getting obsessed with trying out new trucks and especially their cabins.
And so I started adventuring around Europe with a goal to collect money for new trucks. In-game integrated radio stations made it a lot more enjoyable and mods made it more interesting. Graphics are not the best but still very solid.
Sound of wipers going up and down while cleaning my windows off the rain that was hitting the glass, and blinkers ticking pap, pap, pap, pap, really added to the atmosphere.

Conclusion:  It might sound to you that I'm pointing out irrelevant details but what I'm trying to say over here is that everything is so nicely composed that it will give you a good satisfying feeling. Keep in mind this is a simulator and not a game and it will totally depend on your taste. For me it's an interesting title that could keep me busy for 70-100 hours and not more but I have seen people with over 2,000 hours in it, so yeah!

reviewText:
What I like about Euro Truck Simulator 2:

It's my very first time playing a driving game since Late 1990's Nascar, and though I'm an adult and a great driver of U-Hauls, tractors, sports cars, and other fun on and off road vehicles in RL, this gives me a whole new outlook on driving! I've ridden in Rigs, many relatives of mine drive trucks, as well as a friend.  I stayed in my lane mostly (until I'd hit my touch pad on my laptop, haha). I moved my turn signals to A and D since I use my mouse to steer. Q became my brights.

Gotta watch out if you pass up the gas station just a hair, there always seems to be a rig behind you and backing up ends up giving you a violation for a wreck! (Object's distance when that far back on a 1920x1080 resolution is nearly impossible to be able to judge how close that rig behind you stopped)  LOL  I only ran over about 15 cones in the construction area. (yeah, ONLY) haha.

(And a friend of mine was texting (in RL) while driving a rig in the game and she nearly blew through a tool booth! LMBO!!!)

I found it fun.. Some may stress over it.. but to me, it's just a game and it's fun to explore what it is like to drive a rig in a virtual reality setting. Visuals are great! Just wish that camera sound would stop when taking images! Steam uses f12 for me and this game was using both f10 and f12. I deactivated the f10 option but f12 still makes that shutter sound. Steam settings have sounds turned off for ingame captures. No clue how to fix that issue.  I got a lot of speeding tickets too! haha

When I very first started playing, I forgot it was not American and I went down the wrong side of the road .. Another violation! And people keep cutting me off!  But my rating for the fun/ease of use/ new experience - I'd give it a 8/10 myself.

I haven't figured out yet if hazards or high beams affect but no headlights at night = ticket/fine/loss of money. Backing up is HARD for me. I jackknifed more than I care to admit..
♥ Roll on 18 wheeler, Roll on! ♥

I hope you guys can enjoy it as I did. One more note. I used keyboard and mouse.. Mouse to steer. I played 4.1 hours straight my first game.. Must say something about how cool I think it is.. ^.^ (And you don't have to hit E to start the engine. You can hit W as well, which is drive"..)  AND you can add your own music!!!  ( ♥  ♪ ♫ ♪ ♫ ♪ ♫ ♪ ♫ ♪ ♫ ♪ ♫ ♪ ♥ )

Keep an eye on your side view mirrors as you turn... Easy to hit a vehicle or other object (Signs
hoursPlayed: trailers) if your turn is too sharp and getting up some hills is nearly impossible but not impossible :D\n\nYou can also adjust your seats
voteText: position in the seat and other cool little tidbit settings ^.^\n\nAnother note: I've only purchased the base game as it was a good deal but hope to purchase the others later
helpfulPercent: as they drop in price! :D  Have fun truckin' if you do like these types of games! It's great

reviewText: There are titles in the simulation market which can be sold on the novelty factor alone, but tend to be disappointing games.  Euro Truck Simulator 2 is not one of them, it is strangely cathartic, engaging and relaxing. Unlike other niche games, there is a smaller barrier to entry and features a simple control scheme for newcomers.  There are some reservations such as an infuriating penalty system and a lack of vehicles on major highways but these are outweighed by the positives.  Overall, for the fee of 20€, I would highly recommend this driving experience even if it’s not something that would usually be on your radar.

reviewText:
Euro Truck Simulator is a truck simulation game created by SCS Software set in europe. The player can drive across a depiction of europe, visiting its cities, picking up cargos, and delivering them. At the start of the game the player must work for trucking companies as a hired driver, eventually taking out a loan or earning money to purchase a truck and establish their own trucking company.

+ Beautiful World
+ The Legendary Truck Scania
+ Support Multiplayer Servers (Europe 1 - 3)
+ Support For Music

- Bugs
- Sometimes Low FPS 20 - 60
- Some Chauffeurs Are Nervous
- Kick For AFK ( Improving Truck In Repair )

I Recommend ... !

reviewText:
Don't be fooled into taking a quick glance at this game and thinking it's a boring half-broken trucking simulator that you'll never play again after 10 minutes.  This game is the complete opposite of those things.

While there is a bit of a learning curve at first (especially if you aren't from a European country), you can easily find yourself sinking a lot of time into this game.  The map for the game is very expansive, and it will take hundreds of hours of gameplay to discover every motorway, dual carriageway, small country road, and city.

Even with this game being out for over year and a half, the developers continue to provide new updates and DLC that continue to provide new and exciting things to try.  And if they don't provide something you want, the modding community is very large and there are many different sites each with a plethora of different mods you can try (modding is also as easy as dragging and dropping).  Want a fancy Peterbilt, or a map with over 200 cities covering almost all of Europe?  There are mods for those.

In short, you won't be disappointed in this game if you enjoy casual trucking simulators.

reviewText:
I never knew what country music is, knows nothing about trucks, after playing this game for 5 hours straight last week, oh boy, I wished I knew about this game sooner. Nothing beats the feeling driving the truck in 90 km/h while listening to those country music. Got 3000 euros fine the first time I did my delivery, not familiar with the traffic rules in Europe, but you can always reload.

Driving is the core of this game, its relaxing and addictive at the same time. The graphic is breath taking, the musics are good, and the driving mechanic is based on reality, which makes it very comple. And god, those trucks are awesome as ♥♥♥♥, and you can upgrade your trucks from the tires, body, dashboard (incl. accessories), engine, suspensions, paintjobs, basically everything. Every delivery you complete will net you some exp, money and skill point. After you has some dough, you can hire new drivers, trucks and garages.

The map is big enough (without the dlcs), IMO. It takes time to discover every roads to 100%. If you want a relaxing game with no pressure, try this one.

reviewText:
Driving a virtual truck might not seem like the most exiting of things, but ETS 2 manages to achieve the improbable and actually makes it a very relaxing and fun experience to just put on your favourite music on the radio and roll across Europe delivering various goods and growing your trucking empire.
It's one of the best driving simulators around and with great developer support from SCS and frequent updates and map expansions, especially the impressively detailed Scandinavia DLC, there is a lot to like about the game.

Overall a great game from a good developer and one of those games that any good gaming library should have, for those times when you just want to sit back and drive for hours across Europe. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Euro Truck Simulator. Three words which, in isolation, seem innocuous enough, but which when spoken in sequence can put even the most ardent gamer to sleep.

If you’re still reading this, then that means you’re still awake. You passed the first test.

If my tone seems cruel and mocking now, that’s because when I first heard about ETS, I did cruelly mock it. Trucks? Boring. Simulation games? Boring. That’s what my STUPID brain thought when I read the title, and it relayed the various commands so that I might signify my condescension. Fake yawn, patronising shake of the head, roll the eyes. Fart a little bit - my bottom pleading to be involved somehow.

And so I ignored it, for about a year after its release, until I read an article (I forget where, or by whom) which said that even though it sounds like it’ll be boring, it actually isn’t.

It is. It is a bit boring, but in a good way.

First, the meat. ETS is a game where you drive a truck and deliver goods around Europe. You start off doing freight jobs in loaned trucks, but will eventually earn enough to buy your own, which is when you’ll see real money coming in. You’ll continue earning money until you can rent premises, hire people and buy more trucks for them to deliver goods in, earning you even more money. That’s it, really. There’s not much to the business management side of things, so once you’ve got your own truck you could just ignore that aspect entirely. Control options are fairly customisable, which is nice. I play on a 360 pad (very “casual mode”) with all the assists turned on and automatic gearing and whatnot, and it’s lovely. Relaxing. But if you want you can have 50 different buttons on the keyboard devoted to different functions and really take control. The holy grail, of course, is playing with a wheel and decent pedals, but I doubt I’ll ever get the chance to try that out.

After I played the demo until about 3am, I decided to buy ETS. I couldn’t say that I had had a lot of fun, precisely, or that I’d learned anything about what it is to drive a truck, or any other aspect of trucking. But as the rain fell upon my cab in Calais, and the wipers swished hypnotically back and forth, back and forth, I had felt tremendously involved. In that time I’d gone from Manchester to London, then all the way to Scotland on some slow, winding roads, and then belted back down south and across the channel. I’d signalled properly, watched my speed, and stopped at the lights like a good boy. Is this even a proper game? Where are the zombies?

Often, when we talk about games we talk about atmosphere. How does this game conjure the atmosphere or exploring an underwater wreck, or how does this one make you feel like you’re in the middle of a war, running for your life. ETS has an amazing amount of atmosphere: you really will feel like you’re sat in traffic on the M56. And if that sounds mundane, fair enough, it probably is, but somehow this game seeps into your pores and you start to care. You want to make your delivery on time, and you want your cargo to be undamaged, and you want to ease the trailer into the bay like a boss (your first time around this will seem impossible). It can be tremendously satisfying to get things right, and very stressful when things start to go wrong. I remember driving past my exit somewhere in Germany and having to take a huge detour. Pressed for time and with my truck running on fumes, I started driving faster, more recklessly. That job cost me a lot of money, and in real life, would have earned me some serious jail time.

Speaking of jail time, the way fines and penalties are handled in this game is a little odd. There are no rozzers to speak of, and when you, for example, hit another car or run a red light you will automagically be fined a set amount of money, curse under your breath and continue on your way. That’s it. It’s a bit disappointing to me that even if you careen into a mini at 100mph, there will be no real negative consequence to that. A small fine, that’s it. Worse still is the infuriating way speed cameras are handled. If you’re doing 31 in a 30 zone as you pass one, you’ll get a fine. Shouldn’t there be a bit of leeway, like in real life? I’m not sure what the game is “simulating” in that situation.

The AI in this game is hilarious at times, too. I remember once a car flashed me to let me out of a busy junction, and I thought that was great. It didn’t seem like a scripted response at all, and I honked my horn in approval. That’s only even happened once in about 60 hours. More often than not you’ll see drivers stopping dead on the sliproad for no reason, or entering a roundabout in the wrong lane at the wrong time as you pull 22 tons of furniture in their path. I remember one particularly determined driver who got himself wedged under my trailer as he tried to change lanes. I got a big “collision” fine for no reason, and he put his hazards on, pointlessly. I’d like to say this stuff is rare, but usually you’ll see some crazy AI behaviour on every job you take.

Look, I love this game. It’s what I love to play when I want to unwind. Undeniably, it is repetitive. Even if you’re going somewhere new - and on a map this size you often are - you’re still essentially going through the motions. But, like taking a big dump, these motions are very satisfying, and the odd glitches and quirks of the AI add to the charm somehow. It’s a big achievement that a simulation game, such as it is, has managed to find quite so broad an audience. Give the generous demo a try, and I think you’ll soon be seduced by its shiny, chrome encrusted charms.

reviewText:
Driving a truck through europe.....snorefest much?

That was my first thought when I got this game and most people I know share that thought. There was a huge hype over the game tho so I gave it a shot......

...took me ONE tour to hook me up.


Seriously. Whats fun about this game?

Your truck is a big slow brute, almost everything on the road is faster then you, your acceleration is matching a snails and turning takes hours (felt)...WHAT exactly can be fun about it?

For me.....

- its very relaxing to follow the street and be challenged with realistic physics and traffic rules
- visuals are AWESOME if you take the time to look around there are so many details
- a skill system enables you to evolve and improve your own driver and build up a trucking company
- mostly its about the EXPERIENCE, its not a racer, its not a reaction game....it enabley you to do something most people cannot do in real life ----> commanding 800 horse power at your leasure

I am playing it with keyboard and mouse (for steering and looking around) which works out quite well for me once I adjusted various sensetivities. I seriously consider getting me a steering wheel, camera (to enable me to look" around with my head) and pedals for better control tho.

It certainly isnt for everybody. I m just saying you dont know if its your game or not if you dont give it a chance. I "thought" this would never work for me and here I am....happily trucking away while my wife watches me shaking her head :)"

reviewText:
Simulators tend to be hit and miss, but this is no doubt a hit. This is a game where you can chill, as though you are indeed driving through Europe. When you do the larger missions, completion is fabulously rewarding, as is the excitment the game manages to give when you purchase your own truck.

They have managed to get the scaling down of Europe and the speed of time spot on in my opinion. The perfection means that it's not too slow going from one country to another, but there is a certain marathon of time to fare in driving. I think this plays an important role in how much satisfaction the game gives you; getting 20,000 virtual pounds has never felt so good after an hour's drive.

I'm not going to pretend this game is bang on though. Things do end up being repetitive; for example the locations for a company are exactly the same style of building no matter where you are. There are limited AI cars (themselves a bit dim-witted), the motorways could do with being a little bit busier (like rush hour), and the turn off junctions on motorways are extremelly inaccurate.

My suggestions for an update would be to allow the driver to skip a track whilst driving in music, and for the fuel prices to be updated through the internet to match the current prices. Surely that's not too difficult?

That may sound like a proper moan, but these are tiny issues that can't overlap the fact that this is a very well designed game with jaw-dropping physics on the trucks. Just don't tell your friends that this is a more enjoyable game than most action games out there...

reviewText:
Wow, still haven't reviewed this game, even after 50 hours of playing and recording it. Well let me tell you that this can be a very serious, or a very non-serious and arcadey game, depending on how you go about playing the game.

Simulation-y things to do:
Obey traffic lights
Obey speed limit
Obey laws of gravity
Refuel when the tank runs reasonably low
Have traffic accidents once in a while

Non-simulation-y things to do:
Disable speed limiter, race up to 170km/h (might end badly)
Run traffic lights
Crash into cars (for fun, of course)
Roll your truck over, explode into flames (for fun, of course)
Play dubstep as you're road-warrioring around Europe
See if you can make the next fuel station even as you're running on fumes

But, as I said, it depends on how you play it.

If someone said to me, 'Tim, you wanna play this game in which you drive around and all over Europe, chilled like? Look around at the serene scenery and the plush countryside? Listen to the engine purr at the touch of your feet?'

I would buy it. And you should too.

reviewText: Have you ever wondered, why ETS2 is one of the most played games on Steam? You should have, as there is no way getting around this wonderful simulator, at least not if you want to be a real PCGamer... but what makes that sim-game so special?\nEuro Truck Simulator makes it easy for any new players to jump right in and is very suitable for beginners as the options allow for massive customization when it comes to how realistic the game shall be. Talking about beginners, you don't need to have the latest and greatest PC in order to enjoy the game, it even runs on a five year old Intel HD Graphics but trust me, if you're lucky enough to own a high-end graphics card/ a decent rig in general, you will be able to push the graphics to a level on which you might be able to forget that you are just playing a video game! Anyways, if you don't want to sleep, you don't have to, just remove the mark in front of the fatigue simulation and you are free to drive for how long you want! But if you're one of those players, who would give everything for realism, you will also be absolutely pleased by what ETS2 has to offer. Let it be the fuel consumption of your truck or the air brake system, the possibilities for realism fanatics are endless. At that point, I should also mention that the game has great support for various steering wheels and TrackIR to give you the best possible driving experience. It is also possible, to mod the heck out of your personal Euro Truck Simulator version, in order to make it your very own experience. For those of you that aren't very interested in modding, you can also purchase a wide array of DLC packages that will add new parts of Europe or some new tuning options.\nBut does that mean that the game is flawless? No, it's not. Considering the AI drivers' behavior or some of the old parts of the map, there are some minor problems here and there but they definitely don't brake the game or make it unplayable. Just enjoy the game and listen to some of your music in the background, you will not regret it!

reviewText:
First of all, I must say that what makes this game most amazing is that the developers are listening to the Community and constantly pushing out updates to make the game better, or expand upon it.

I've owned this game for nearly three years now and have over 500 hours (as of when writing this review) and combined with what the developers constantly updated, the game is still great. The graphics and scenery of this game are amazing although I believe that it could be improved upon in the future as well.

The game reflects simulation well, you pick up a cargo, you deliver across countries and drop it off, this process will not be enjoyable for people who are looking for a fast paced games or non-repetitive games as developing your in-game company will take a long time, from completing a delivery that might take over 1 hour of real life time, to having enough money to purchase a truck for you and your employees, hiring employees for your company and purchasing/upgrading garages.

The game also supports steering wheels which is a very important aspect to this kind of game, and it also supports mods which there are thousands of that were created by the community members that allow to expand upon the basic game.

Now moving back to the development of the game, the developers are doing an amazing job. With the release of Going East! and Scandinavia expansion packs, this really opened up more kinds of deliveries, more amazing scenery (Mountains!), more diverse roads and most importantly, more locations to travel and explore to from the basic game. In the basic game (without Going East! and Scandinavia), the motorways were pretty boring to drive on as 70% (estimate) of the time you would spend continuously driving on the motorway which can get quite boring really fast especially if you have a long journey ahead of you. However, Scandinavia and Going East! opened up more diverse type of roads rather than just plain motorways which I really liked.

To top off the review, this game has an unofficial Multiplayer mod that you can download and play as long as you own an Euro Truck Simulator 2 copy, it allows you to meet and play with your friends in a single server which is a really nice addition to this type of game, now if there could only be an official Multiplayer!

reviewText:
[Review based on MP Mod]

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is an anomaly in itself and the multiplayer is very well done because of the sudden and unexpected moments it creates. The truck driving and beautifully weaved scenery gives you goose bumps for the immersion it hands to you. The game itself is quite unique in its own respect as it breaks all the arbitrary boundaries and restrictions that many other simulators place on the table. Euro Truck Simulator 2 liberates itself and goes above all the others.

But why is Euro Truck Simulator 2 fun?

Euro Truck Simulator 2 completely redefines the epitome of the simulator. Even though it is quite esoteric in the way it is built, it still offers a wide array of features which all come together to make it a fabulous game.

I consider Euro Truck Simulator 2 the leader of all simulation games and is very idiosyncratic to me as it gives me open world features which lead me to have  a freedom of choice in all my actions including  as where i want to go around Europe. Aswell as that, the multiplayer enviroment allows me to junket around and witness the often hilarious moments of seeing others jack-knifing their trucks in traffic which leads them on to rage in chat.

Many open world games are quite infinitesimal; but not Euro Truck Simulator.

The world is large and has many different high poly models which help it represent what it is. These models include world wonders such as the Eiffel Tower.

Once you are immersed in the world you often become oblivious of your real life chores and you struggle choosing between bed time or Just... one.. more.. job!". Your real life will become a red herring to Euro Truck.

Although this game was released in a precocious state it has been patched and made better with recent additions and when Multiplayer was added. Multiplayer has revolutionalized the state of the game for many players
recommended:
multiplayer has paved the way for social interactions between players and players making rules as to what is propriety.

Now what is Euro Truck on its own?
Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a vast and open world game with a high amount of immersion thanks to its highly detailed cabin with fantastic textures including normal maps and high poly models. These highly detailed models allow for us to revel and bask in all their eternal glory and is just scintillating in the way they are designed exactly like the real trucks.

The sound engine in the game is just phenomenal ranging from turbo whistles to indicators and to idle truck noises it really pops into your head wherever you are and becomes very ubiquitous.

Overall I consider Euro Truck Simulator an absolutely marvellous game which all compiles together to create a fantastic experience through sound

social aspects and even the driving mechanics.

Just don't mention the Artificial Intelligence. (atleast it's disabled in MP)

reviewText:
I've been fan of trucking games since Hard Truck 2: King of the Road came out and i also happend to be fan of any kind of open world games, but thats just one of the many reasons i love Euro Truck Simulator 2.

As you might have guessed the game is about simulating trucking, your main job is delivering cargo around Europe and in case you want full simulation you will have to refuel once in a while, get sleep when you get tired, repair your truck and so on. It's important to note that the trucks are very fun to drive and feel pretty realistic, and once you gather enough money you can upgrade and mod them.

What also is worth to be mentioned is the huge modding community which is taking part into improving the game a lot, for example there is multiplayer mod that came out few months ago, so now you can truck with your buddies as well!

Some people will find this game boring at first, but once in a while its good taking rest of fast-paced games and just drive, chill and listen to your favorite radio station meanwhile, not to mention the fun situations you will get into. :)

reviewText:
When I first heard about the game, I was immediately put off by the notion of driving trucks. I'm not a racing fan, as the novelty of driving supercars has long since worn off. With the plethora of so called simulators flooding the market (farm simulator, goat simulator, you get the idea), I avoided these sim games until I watched my friend play on his PC with a wheel setup. I was immediately awe-struck at how good and immersive driving a truck felt on a wheel setup, by the time I got off from his PC, I noticed already 2 hours had passed. I haven't been this immersed in a game like this in a long, long time.

What really piqued my interest in the game is how you begin from scratch of just having opened a truck company with no trucks of your own. You earn your keep and livelihood driving trucks for other companies. On long hauls across the European landmarks, with Brian Eno's music playing on the radio, I contemplated how nice it would be to finally own a truck of my own and hire drivers to do my bidding. A couple of weeks later and with enough savings, I was able to buy my very own first truck. But that was just the beginning of it.

If you're looking to play destruction derby or Forza/GT type experience, then you're looking in the wrong section. ETS2 offers something unique and captivating other driving games fail to offer.

This game also has an amazing mod community which has a lot to offer.

Very highly recommended for everyone who are sick of playing cops vs racers & driving supercars/ sportscars over the same landscape over and over. Its a nice change in pace and you will love every moment of it.

The environments are ridiculously beautiful, the weather patterns are a joy to see in action, the trucks are shiny and gorgeous (and customizable), the driving is challenging *and* fun, and there's also a business management game built into all of that.  Pretty cool.

So yeah.

Trucks.

More fun than you'd expect.

reviewText:
Euro Truck Simulator 2; its often difficult to explain to people what makes this game so immersive and fun to play. You can easily put hours into this game and never realise. After putting 162 hours into the game myself, I figured I should leave a review!

Basically, this game gives you the freedom to travel the roads of Europe, driving any truck you desire, completing jobs from Aberdeen in Scotland to Lublin in Poland and everything in between. The trucks are fully customisable, and there is also a level up system, allowing for longer distance jobs, eco driving, more important cargo and better trucks unlocked.

You may purchase your own garages in the cities you visit across Europe, and hire drivers to work for your company. The more you earn, the more upgrades you can do to your garages and the more trucks you can buy as well.

The devs at SCS are excellent and come out with great updates and DLCs. Also, if you're a modder, this game has a great modding community and awesome scope for mods of all kinds.

It is a great simulation game, if you have a wheel and pedals to use, the experience is even better. But you can also use a normal gamepad if you desire rather than keyboard, it is up to you how you play. The trucks drive like they should do, you can feel the weight of the trailers you pick up.

One of the things I love most about this game is the environment. SCS have done a great job with creating the world of ETS2, and each country has a slightly different feel. I love driving through the Austrian mountains as well as the countryside in the UK. The weather and lighting is also brilliantly done.

I have owned ETS2 since February 2013, and I still enjoy playing. I highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
This is an odd game to review because, like Crusader Kings II, it's fun - but a very specific kind of fun that might not be for everyone. This is obviously a driving sim with a healthy mix of logistics and entrepreneurship and it's hard to sell that to people who aren't already interested in it, which is why the trailer to this game looks lost and confused. People like videos that highlight the action and, honestly, this isn't a game that has a lot of it. This game doesn't have explosions, it's relaxing, if anything. You transport objects and make money doing it. For some people, this is boring, but for the target audience, that's a cool concept in and of itself. It's probably the meat of what people describe as being the intangible backbone of what makes this game good.

What makes life in this game tolerable?

Well, the first thing that comes to mind is that an enormous amount of time was spent trying to get the roads and scenery to look convincing. If you're on the M5 and pause the game, go to Google and drop the streetview cam on the approximate spot where your truck is, it's going to be pretty darn similar to what you'll see. Road signs will toned down and simplified, but the traffic cams will not. People without cars will soon learn what a pain in the butt they are for commuters. Road patterns like interstate on/off ramps will be recycled, but that's pretty much what happens in real life as well.

When driving down an interstate, it's obviously not in anyone's interest to make a two hour trip to Bristol actually take two real world hours, so time and distance are abridged. So are cities and the insane traffic patterns and congestion associated with it. This means that, sometimes, it's O.K. to go to London.

The game can be as accurate as you like when it comes to operating your truck, from incomprehensible (how gears work in real life) to arcade (magic transmission - W means go).

Radio stations are real. If you choose, you can have your truck radio stream the actual radio stations of whatever country you want and whatever languages they are broadcast in. This is a pretty fun feature and adds to the immersion in the game.

The biggest downside? Traffic. It's inconsistent and has a few bugs. The most pressing one is that NPC drivers have no concept of their own safety. Honestly, I'm not sure what their pathing is, but they seem to cruse right into you as if you were not there, even with proper signaling. That said, they're better than I expected for AI behavior for the most part. If you signal that you want to turn across an oncoming lane, the cars will ocasionally stop and flash their lights to indicate that they're willing to stop for you to get across.

An unrelated disappointment is that weather is not dynamic to your location, it's a global setting. So, the chance of rain in Glasgow is the same as Paris.

The final remarkable disappointment I can think of is that, like I mentioned earlier, roads and cities are abridged. And while I definitely don't mind avoiding cities for their suicidal traffic AI, they're very unconvincing for the most part. Unless it's is a larger city that they are particularly proud of, like Klagenfurt and Venice, the majority of cities" are maybe ten blocks? Residential areas and all? It makes the final destination a repetitive anticlimactic end to a long drive.

The game is still being worked on
date: obviously. Scandinavia will be released at some point and there's already a host of mods for amateur-created areas. At some point
recommended: it's possible that the drawbacks I've mentioned will be taken care of. Even if they aren't
hoursPlayed: there are far worse and game breaking problems that it could have
voteText: but doesn't. The devs have put a tremendous amount of time into this unfathomably large and complicated project and it's solid because of that. As far as a truck driving sim goes
helpfulPercent: this is probably as good as it gets for the foreseeable future.\n"

reviewText:
Positives:
- Does exactly what it says - simulates truck driving in Europe very well.
- Developer support has been fantastic.  The game feels very different compared to what it was in April 2013 compared to December 2013 due to various improvements (dynamic auto transmission, dynamic fuel, other tweaks)
- New trucks are being added to the game for free.  In other games, these would be DLCs.
- DLCs are very modestly priced, great value for money.
- Very easy to install mods from a highly active modding community.
- SCS official forums are a great place to ask for help in a mature manner.  i.e. Very informative, but not suitable for the attention-deficit crowd.

Negatives:
- You'd better love trucks and simulation or else you'd die of boredom.
- Trucks probably handle a little too well around tight bends.
- Some bends and gradient changes can be smoother.
- UK motorway design is very Continental.
- AI traffic have their annoying quirks  (but the developer says they are working on improving this).

reviewText: This is an awesome truck driver simulator game.  I play with an xbox Gempad controller and use the joystick to steer and it works very well.  The game is immersive and let's you play your own music through the radio.  You can work for other companies making deliveries or you can buy a truck and start your own company and even hire other drivers.  You get to drive in some nice scenery, realistic traffic and even get fines for not obeying traffic signals.  I'd recommend this game - it's a high quality truck driver/delivery simulator.
voteText: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A lot of times you hear the word simulator and you get a little intimidated, expecting a steep learning curve.  But this game does a good job of easing the new player in.  It's also a great game to unwind to.  You can pick a radio station to listen to (or put in your own music), and relax to some music as you drive to your next destination.

There's a ton of customization options for your truck, if you are into that sort of thing.  But this game has a lot to offer casual players as well.  I would definitely recommend this game, especially if you enjoy driving and you are looking for a change of pace from the usual racing games/crash simulators.

Also, you can play this game with a keyboard or mouse, but I highly recommend a steering wheel.  I ended up buying a Logitech GT racing wheel with pedals.  My daughter makes fun of me because I have this fancy setup, and all I do is deliver cargo with it.

reviewText: What an absolutely fantastic game! I have played this game for nearly 4 years and it is astonishing. As you can tell by the amount of hours I have on it, you can see that this is a game that I am very fond of. The single player is good as it gives you the opportunity to build your own company from scratch and also use some of the awesome modifications that the games brilliant modding community has created. Then we get to the multiplayer....... this mod brings a whole new life to the game as it allows you to truck around Europe with your friends! reviewText: My playtime says it all. Whether it's just to enjoy the scenery as you putz around the European countryside, or go all out and mod in fantastically heavy loads and try to get them to their destination on time in a hilariously underpowered truck, you just can't go wrong with this driving simulator with a business simulator tacked on. And not only is ETS2 a great way to chill out and listen to tunes, its also a somber reminder that once a business starts making enough money it can effectively ignore the law, run roughshod over the populace and pay the meager penalties imposed upon it by spineless governments.

This is my truck. There are many like it, but this one is mine.
My truck is my best friend. It is my life. I must master it as I must master my life.
My truck, without me, is useless. Without my truck, I am useless. I must drive my truck true. I must drive straighter than my enemy who is trying to ram me. I must out-turn him before he cuts me off because he's a ♥♥♥♥ing South American. My truck and I know that what counts in war is not the deliveries we undertake, the noise of our stacks, nor the smoke from burning sweet diesel.
My truck is human, even as I, because it is my life. Thus, I will learn it as a brother. I will learn its weaknesses, its strength, its parts, its accessories, its signals and its gears. I will keep my truck clean and ready, even as I am clean and ready. We will become part of each other.
Before GabeN, I swear this creed. My truck and I are the defenders of my country. We are the masters of our enemy. We are the saviors of my life.
So be it, until victory is America's and there is no enemy, but peace!

reviewText:
Have you ever played a game and found, for example, an inflatable bat as a weapon in a sci-fi setting that turned out to be absolutely lethal? Or a giant foam hand that sends mooks flying into the stratosphere, never to be seen from again? These are generally called Lethal Joke Items, and are usually something you laugh at for the silliness and keep using for their inherent power.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is the Lethal Joke Item of videogames.

I bought this purely for giggles. 'Oh look, a trucking game, hahaha!' I though. 'I bet it's boring!'. I was completely wrong. The game boasts a high level of accuracy to real-world trucks, and the amount of care put into it is staggering. Dials, readings, even seats and mirrors are recreated with obvious care and detail, not to mention the audio. The gameplay also has varying levels of complexity to allow for both hardcore simulator fans and casual drivers to play on the same field (even more-so with the Multiplayer mod, still under development). The game manages to keep itself fresh, breaking up the long motorway driving with tricky country roads, or even throwing roadworks, tollbooths and traffic at you. And the customisation can keep people like me occupied for hours, tweaking and twiddling with paintjobs, wheels, even the lights. Coupled with a side of business management in the form of hiring and training drivers, there's enough to keep players going.

However, it's not without its downsides. Unless a player takes out loans, getting your company going is a slog. On top of that, the business management could do with some expanding (such as having hired drivers appearing on roads, or simply being more involved in setting criteria for jobs). However, these are minor issues on top of a rather excellent simulator cake that, quite frankly, surprised me with how good it actually is. The premise is a bit silly, but discount it at your own peril. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is still a quite good game.

reviewText:
Very good, cathartic experience.  I attempted to play this game as it was intended, but I soon discovered that being a complete and total sociopath was much more fun and rewarding.  Like my namesake Sanic, I made it my mission to make every delivery as fast as humanly possible, regardless of mechanical, monetary, or medical consequence.  On a 2 lane highway I'll drive down the center line, leaving a long line of cars behind me, unable to overtake.  On 3 lanes or more, I'll sit in the center lane, watch my mirrors, and if anyone tries to overtake me, I'll move into their lane to cut them off.  If I get lucky I cut them off in the process of overtaking me, charging me 400 Euros for a traffic violation, and sending the zippy little sedan into the median in order to wait for ADAC.

I find its helpful to yell obscenities at the foreigners.  On the way to Dresden from Berlin, I drove a minivan off the road.  As I passed them I leaned my head out the window and shouted That was for Pearl Harbor!"

I've collected enough speeding violations and vehicular damage (both to my own vehicle and to those around me) that I'm now several thousand Euros in debt.  I don't exactly know how their monopoly money converts to actual currency like USD
date: but its more debt than I'm willing to pay off.  I've now made it my mission to become a bigger drain on the European economy than Greece.\n\nThe internet radio stations were a nice touch.  It really topped of the atmosphere of the game
recommended: and taught me how to pronounce the funny made-up words they put in the game like Poznań and Szczecin.\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
This game without a doubt is awesome, but is missing a few key elements for it to be complete.

I'm not sure why, but I got in the mood to drive a truck with a trailer. For some reason, the challenge of wanting to be able to maneuver a tight turn was a yearning. Therefore I was willing to try the best of the best so they were saying.

Upon choosing a character skin, truck skin, and company logo I embarked on my journey to become a trucker. The menu is extremely friendly (and very chic) and allows you to change almost anything. Controller compatibility is also accommodated here to a great extent. ETS2 has great gameplay. Steering, driving, shifting, turning, backing up all feel quite accurate. Don't go around holding the gas all the time though. I got a few speeding tickets that way. This would be an ideal dream for those who played Grand Theft Auto and loved to drive by the rules. Actually following the rules of the road in such a big machine is quite tough, at least from a first person view. Lining up the truck nicely when coming out from the curb to see oncoming traffic poses quite the challenge. This game definitely gave me an inside look of the difficulties truckers face when driving. There are a lot of side jobs that are offered and jobs that you can take upon yourself counting towards for your company. I would highly suggest practicing driving in reverse as it is one of the most difficult tasks you may encounter. The ability to build up a company and hire drivers is an enjoyable experience, but can feel like a grind at first. What was a neat feature was that sometimes the AI would let you merge when changing lanes, and sometimes there were AI that crashed into one another which would lead them to turn their hazards on. Sounds cool, up until your stuck behind crashed AI that won't PULL OVER TO THE SIDE OF THE ROAD! It's hard going around signs and cars with a giant tractor trailer.

Visuals are extremely appealing and all the truck details seem to be there. Roads are complete with beautiful scenery and weather conditions. Besides driving in the sun, night or the rain, it would have been nice to be challenged with a bit of snow.

Sounds seem as real as they get. It's nice driving and simply hearing a motor running.

What I do want to make a few remarks about is the fact that you aren't able to drive up on ferries and board them when going across seas... which was sort of disappointing considering. Another disappointing fact was drivers don't seem to have any personality. Bland AI seems to be driving around everywhere. I wouldn't mind seeing someone react to me honking, or some crazy idiot driving swerving through lanes or trying to cut me off, or the slow guy that everyone passes. I know this game was meant for proper driving but I'd love to see a few collision mechanics at their best. What would be a huge deal breaker would be to add pedestrians. Yes it could be gruesome (so add an option to turn it off?) but watching over for civilians crossing is something to keep in mind when driving!  All that being said, I would still like to see a truck driving simulating game that puts the player in a city where they have to make turns in busy pedestrian and traffic scenarios. Sure it would be hard to make entire maps for cities, but even have a few scenarios to choose from with a few tight roads to outmaneuver through would be cool. On the road in the country side, adding wild animals would be another idea to think about. Would make night driving interesting. This may be veering to close to reality but adding actual police cars that pull the truck over would intensify the experience. Imagine a car chase with a truck!

The game is good and would recommend a purchase on sale. I really hope though they do add what I mentioned into future games as I would literally like to foresee the trip on and off the road.

Rating 7.45/10

***Also, having a walk through on how to use the mods would help!

***Local co-op or split screen would also make this game un-real!

EDIT SEPT 2015 : They have greatly improved the interface of this game. Everything is a bit easier to manage.

ScreenShots :
Proud owner of my first IVECO truck

Even if it's green, check the small signs out that indicate to yield

Passing a coach and another semi

Visual

reviewText:
Personal Rating: I love driving my truck!
Classic Rating: ★★★★☆

ETS2 is an overall good driving simulator, it's got many different features and they fit very well together.
These are some of ETS2's strong points:

● Good playability, easy handling/steering (I'm using an XBOX 360 Controller, but Steering Wheels are also supported)
● Nice gameplay: you don't just drive; you can run your own company, hire drivers, take a loan if you need money to buy a truck or personalize it - the game offers many (unlockable) items for your trucks. You also advance in your driver's career, adding skills every time you gain enough XP; those upgrades are needed to take longer trips, carry fragile/expensive/dangerous cargos which let you earn money faster.
● You can listen to your favourite music in-game, being it a Streaming Radio or MP3 files.
● ETS2 is highly moddable and there is plenty of Mods: I can suggest ProMods" for Single Player and "ETS2 Multiplayer Mod" which adds a living layer to the game (only human player are in there).
● You can have your favourite avatar and plate
date:
registering at World of Trucks website (they will also give you a free key for a "Metallic Paint Jobs" DLC).


Some downsides too:

● The AI is not the best
recommended: sadly. You'll have to pay a lot of attention when driving near crossings or when switching lanes
hoursPlayed: because the AI drives faster than you and it doesn't care very much about you; a little delay in your maneuver and some car can easily hit you - and yeah
voteText: you're the one being fined - always.\n● Mods: they're cool but you should chose wisely and do not draw the longbow. Some game breaking is to be expected
helpfulPercent: so always save your game before adding a new Mod. Another problem with them is that if you want to remove any
votesHelpful: you'll have to reload a previously saved game and all of your gameplay with that Mod will be just gone; so

reviewText:
Product received for free

Experience the big rigs you dreamt of behind the wheels as the driver. It's a simulator which means you have got to be patient while you develop driving skills. The driver skills are a great way to upgrade the driving experience.

It's not just about going places and admiring the scenery. You have got cash which means you gotta bank it. You start as an employee but sooner or later, with more jobs and more money, you get to have your own rig and build your own company. This is where I just love the gameplay! Especially when you are looking at the showroom and the expensive choices that feels just about real to make you value your hard earned income.

There is a very dynamic weather available that can go from a quite sunny to a gushing thunderstorm that can test your road skills. The night cycle is really dark and you can customise headlights to view better. Nothing becomes frustrating. The cargo you carry come in different varieties and payloads.

For my final verdict, I give this game 9/10. I have avoided a perfect 10 because in my opinion, a much more interactive traffic AI and damage physics would be rewarding!

reviewText:
Euro Truck Simulator 2 is, on the surface, a simulation game about driving trucks. Simple, right? Not as much as you might think. The bones and meat are a driving game, yet it’s so much more than that. It’s making those late night deliveries, driving through thunderstorms, and racing down freeways to make sure those Just-In-Time deliveries are delivered, well, just in time. It’s those situations that take the game to another level. Even when it’s a lazy drive though, the game is still great. In my opinion, the cities are a little bland, but where the game really shines is in the landscapes. Countrysides look fantastic, from the rolling hills and fields of sunflowers to the trees swaying in the breeze and rays of sun illuminating the pavement ahead of you. The game has a lot of content, and does a great job with what it gives you. Driving, doing deliveries, obeying traffic laws, it’s just fun. Of course, that isn’t all the fun to be had…

Being only about 4 hours into the game, I can’t speak much about all that you can do, so I’ll just tell you about some of my experiences.  My first experience was in the demo, where I learned how to drive while responding to traffic flow, obeying traffic rules, and even parking a trailer (harder that it looks) in a simple and fun tutorial. My second experience found me being cut off by some jerk during a peaceful delivery, chasing him down at terminal velocity, and then spotting and proceeding to drive through a meadow of sunflowers (so pretty :D), which eventually led to the detachment of my trailer and first ever service call for engine trouble. As fun as the game’s core is, it also teaches you about yourself, and allows you to stray off the conventional path a bit.

Sometimes it's fun to follow the rules and soak in the scenery, and sometimes it's fun to be a little unconventional. There's no right" and "wrong" way to play this game. It's your game

reviewText:
I never thought i will ever like such game. I always thought it‘s very boring and repetitive and it will be fun only for an hour or so. But i was wrong. I decided to risk and buy this and i didn‘t regret this. The game is great. It looks repetitive and boring but when you play it somehow time flies very fast. It‘s very relaxing game for me. Just open the beer, turn on the in game radio (which by the way has real stations) or your music library and start driving. It really feels very good. Especially when you‘re driving at night on narrow roads while raining.
The controls are very precise, trucks have fully functioning dashboard. Everything you do is displayed correctly on in-game dashboard, from wheel turning to wipers and turn signals. The game is designed to play with a steering wheel, it really adds to the game. I tried to play it with an xbox gamepad before, but it wasn‘t so fun.
The graphics can be ugly at times and sometimes it‘s great. Especially at night while raining, it looks amazing. Worst thing about graphics is that the game does not support AA. The performance is not very good too. Bearing in mind that the graphics is not the strongest side of the game the performance should be much better. You need quite a powerful computer to play it on high settings. But it's nowhere near unplayable. It just could be better in this department.
The game has plenty of mods which adds new maps, trailers, logos or improve the graphics so the game will not get boring for a long time.
Don‘t think and just buy it, especially if you have a steering wheel and you love drving games, this is a must have.

reviewText:
Euro Truck Simulator 2 is an amazing game, the amount of detail which has gone into this game is spectacular. This game may be labeled Indie but don't let that discourage you, the attention to the finer details and the quality surpasses many AAA titles. ETS2 is an absolutely shining example of what a simulation game should be. This game offers amazing value and should not be confused with the many shovelware simulation games which continue to be pumped out on an almost weekly basis.

Not only is the game amazing but so is the team behind it. 2 years past initial release and ETS2 is still seeing frequent updates which offer both improvements and additional content of which many of these are offered as free upgrades to the original game.

Pros

Some of the small but amazing elements which make this great:

- This game doubles as both a truck driving simulation and management game. As you progress through the game you obtain the funds to hire workers, expand your garage and purchase additional trucks.

- The map is virtually endless and feels immensely larger than I have seen in any other game I have ever played. After ~25 hours play time I've only explored 15% of the available area.

- The AI is awesome. They abide by road rules, use indicators when turning, provide ample space for pulling out once you begin enter the lane they occupy. Not only that but they overtake slower cars, adjust themselves and continue after their path is interrupted and more.

- Licensed truck brand names with multiple visual and performance impacting upgrade paths which are unlocked as you progress.

- Places an emphasis on playing the game as if you were a truck driver. The environment, physics and mechanics of the game force you to behave as if you were really driving a truck. To some this may feel restrictive but in my opinion it adds a good amount to the realism of the game.

Cons

Of course, having said all this no games are without flaws. The issues I have with this game are largely related to focus on more refining what is already an amazing game, these are:

- The lack of vibration (Xbox controller) makes driving feel too stable.

- The lack of roadkill on the roads, leaves/branches falling from the trees and blowing around on the ground and small number of pedestrians are a missing element of the game which would certainly add to the realism.

Overall a 9/10 rating for this deceptively enjoyable game which is great for both small and long gaming sessions.

reviewText: I have over 3 million miles in real world semi's in 3 countries. I have driven just about every type of truck, hauled most types of loads, and did so for nearly 18 yrs. Since being forced into early retirement for medical reasons. I have tried every truck simulator out there, looking for a means to keep my skills sharp. Though this is based in Europe and it's primary focus is on COE's. This is the most realistic semi/ truck simulator out there. The world dynamic's are the most true to life I have ever seen. The shifting actually behaves like it should in a real truck. This is by far the best truck simulator out on the market. Can't wait for one to be done for America and Austrailia.\n\nIn no other truck simulator out there, could I drive from the 1st person view. This one I haven't had to take it out of it. The views are spot on, the feel that comes thru is fantastic. All you need is a real truck cab mockup, a vibrating device tied to the engine noise, rumble strips and with a large enough screen, it's doubtful you would realize this was just a game enviroment. The only downfall I have found, the engine noise level inside the cab is way too low. I'm used to being able to drive by the sound without gauges, because of this I have to look from time to time. Generally I find this to be a worthy value and a great trainer aid. I am glad I found this simulator here on Steam. I'v also added some DLC mods as well as other mods that expand the map, trailer types and cargo. Makes it much more to life. But ETS2 is still a great starting point on its own.  Highly recommend.

reviewText:
I saw this game was the Deal of the Day about a week ago, and so I checked it out. It appeared to be one of those forgettable games with a generic name that was just trying to cash in on based on just the picture from Steam's store page, but I was intrigued anyway because I love all things cars and trucks, though I've mostly been stuck as a car hobbyist and racing genre fan, and never played driving simulation games. Based on the reviews I saw, this one was worth checking out--so I bought it and the Going East DLC.

Short summary: this game is awesome in so many different ways. You start out as a low tier leveled business owner, and they don't give you any benefits of the doubt--you have so little money, you don't even get your own truck (yet). You can work for other companies, using their trucks to deliver cargo to a handful of cities across Europe. You have to obey all traffic laws (I made the mistake of rolling through a red light because I hadn't noticed they were there to be obeyed, and was charged a fine), and you have to deliver the cargo in a timely manner. If you damage the truck you're working with, the repair cost is deducted from your pay. The time you have to finish the job is also pretty relaxed--this is no Crazy Taxi, though they do have skill upgrades that allow you access to more time sensitive jobs that pay more for the benefit of a quick job.

Speaking of which, yes, you level up in this game, and this is also great. You can level up in different ways such as in fuel conservation, where you use less fuel and therefore save more money, or you can unlock a number of different jobs by leveling up your training in different areas. High valued cargo? Check. Fragile cargo? Yep. All of these give you access to even more jobs from the extensive list you already had, and you're able to pick the jobs that pay more (it's also great to pick jobs where the delivery is in a city you've never visited, so you explore more of the map and see new sights).

Control-wise, this game also plays extremely well. At first, my time with the controls was chaotic. I've been using a 360 controller to play, and I tried to mess with too much at once, and ended up getting stuck in parking lots because I couldn't figure out how to reverse (ha). If you want to use a controller, I'd suggest not changing the controls from the standard they pick for you at first. Drive around a bit before you decide to change anything.

Moving on, as you make money doing jobs using another company's truck, the bank will eventually contact you and let you know they're offering you a loan. It's enough to buy your first truck, but you'll have to be diligent in making sure you make enough money each day to make your loan payments. With your own truck, you're free to explore the map without a time limit (though you do pay for gas!), finding new truck dealers, farms/factories/cargo drop offs, recruitment agencies, and even future garages that you can buy to expand your grasp in the truck business industry across Europe. Once you work hard at that, the bank will increase your credit limit--allowing you to upgrade your garage if you wish, allowing you to buy additional trucks and hire drivers for you.

Driving simulation now gives way to business management, and this is pure enjoyment of the genre here. You have a number of garages you can obtain later on in the game once you have enough money, but at first, you'll just be buying another truck and assigning it to the additional space in your garage, where you can hire a driver to use. You can use any recruitment agency you've found to hire a driver, and from there you can hire them based on their skills and rating. Not only do they also level up, you can choose how you want them to work. For example, I chose to have my first hired driver focus on long distance jobs, since I myself was focused on shorter jobs that dealt with fragile or valuable cargo. Your hired drivers will also improve their rating over time, as they constantly are driving and working to improve their skills, though you have the authority to fire them if you so wish.

Last but not least--part of the charm in this game is just driving. It felt great to be driving a truck pulling 16 tons of cargo down the highways of Europe, discovering new cities and fulfilling contracts. I knew that with each job I completed, I was a tiny bit closer to paying off my loans, proving my worth in the industry, and making enough for that next truck or next upgrade. Also, the game has a radio feature, which lets you listen to live streams of a great selection of European radio stations--yes, real stations in real time while driving in a Euro truck simulation--and this is awesome. Last night while playing this game, I was driving my truck to a city I'd never seen before, pulling tons of cargo in the dead of night. Only once in a while would another car drive by because of the time, so I was mostly alone on the road. The radio station was playing some older American rock hits between commercials in another language. I was able to zone out. It was simply beautiful to just drive alone on a highway at night, listening to classic rock. I've never played a game that makes you feel so relaxed, so in awe of everyday things...and I've played thousands upon thousands of games. This game does it right.

I can't really say this game surprised me--based on the list of positive reviews, this game is a hit with many. But to think a game named Euro Truck Simulator 2 could be one of those games where you're watching the time get later and later and you think to yourself, Just one more

reviewText:
I haven't been playing this game for very long, but I am really enjoying it so far and can definitely see many more hours ahead of me soon. ETS2 is a very relaxing, enjoyable, challenging and therapeutic game with so much to do and so many things to achieve. The concept is incredibly simple but as an actual game it works so well, it is difficult to explain why it's so fun, but just is!

You start off as a cargo truck driver for hire, doing small or large jobs for money so that you can form your own business with your own fully customisable trucks in a beautiful realistic environment. The cities and routes are not 100% accurate and not as long (that would be ridiculous) but it doesn't matter. There is still hundreds upon hundreds of hours of game play on offer and fantastic scenery all around the developers vision of Europe in this amazing simulator.

This time last year, I would have said that I do not understand how a truck simulator could be any fun as ever since I was a child I have questioned the fun factor of simulation games, but I am so glad that I spent £7.50 for the collection (ETS, ETS2, Bus Driver, Trucks and Trailers, Scania Truck Driving Simulator and plenty of DLC for ETS2), an absolutely amazing bargain.  Some of the best money I have ever spent and I have only played the one game of the collection so far!

ETS2 is worth every penny, so if you see it even cheaper than it's full retail price pick it up and you won't regret it. For the sake of £3.75, you should just buy it anyway!

reviewText: Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a breathtaking game unmatched by any other. While driving across beautiful landscapes, manage your business, hire and fire drivers, fully customize your truck, and play through the most moving story any game has to offer. One man, alone, no shoulders to cry on, no crutches to help him stand, must strive to avoid bankruptcy in an unforgiving and realistic environment. The graphics are stunning, the driving is amazingly realistic, and the dynamic environment with moving cars is mind boggling. If the player turns on his blinker to make a turn, there is a chance that the car opposite of him will stop and let him make the turn. And when a player collides with another vehicle or object, the truck actually takes damage that costs money to repair, is deducted from the payment if the damage was done to the trailer. I can't think of any other game with realism as immersive as that. The leveling system is even better then that in games well known for unique and superior leveling systems such as the Call of Duty franchise and the classic E.T. for Atari. It provides this unique learning experienc that you can get no where else, making you feel as though while your character levels up, you gain a certain understanding of the real world. There were a few downsides of the game, though. For example, this game does not give you the experience needed to qualify for a CDL-A, which disappointed me, given the exemplary story and graphics. Also, it does not provide you with a steering wheel or pedal set for the complete Euro Truck Simulator experience. While most game designers wouldn't, I expected this games creators, or artists, if you will, to put themselves where everyone knows they belong: Above the rest of us. All in all, 10/10 must have, with an ending sure to bring tears to your eyes.

reviewText: This game is one of the best games out there. Not because of the game itself (wich is great!), but because of SCS Software - the best team of developers ever! They add new content to the game all the time, even though it was released years ago! And, most of the new content is free! Can you even imagine that? Besides that, there's a great comunity of players, mod creators and developers hanging out on SCS forums - a place where you can post your ideas for the game, and chances are, you'll see them come to life in one of the next patches. (Mind you, ideas have to be realistic... and there's already a big wishlist there...) ;-)\n\nSo, buy the game. Even if you don't believe trucking can be fun... Strangely enough - it is. And it's highly addictive. :)

reviewText:
I saw this game was the Deal of the Day about a week ago, and so I checked it out. It appeared to be one of those forgettable games with a generic name that was just trying to cash in on based on just the picture from Steam's store page, but I was intrigued anyway because I love all things cars and trucks, though I've mostly been stuck as a car hobbyist and racing genre fan, and never played driving simulation games. Based on the reviews I saw, this one was worth checking out--so I bought it and the Going East DLC.

Short summary: this game is awesome in so many different ways. You start out as a low tier leveled business owner, and they don't give you any benefits of the doubt--you have so little money, you don't even get your own truck (yet). You can work for other companies, using their trucks to deliver cargo to a handful of cities across Europe. You have to obey all traffic laws (I made the mistake of rolling through a red light because I hadn't noticed they were there to be obeyed, and was charged a fine), and you have to deliver the cargo in a timely manner. If you damage the truck you're working with, the repair cost is deducted from your pay. The time you have to finish the job is also pretty relaxed--this is no Crazy Taxi, though they do have skill upgrades that allow you access to more time sensitive jobs that pay more for the benefit of a quick job.

Speaking of which, yes, you level up in this game, and this is also great. You can level up in different ways such as in fuel conservation, where you use less fuel and therefore save more money, or you can unlock a number of different jobs by leveling up your training in different areas. High valued cargo? Check. Fragile cargo? Yep. All of these give you access to even more jobs from the extensive list you already had, and you're able to pick the jobs that pay more (it's also great to pick jobs where the delivery is in a city you've never visited, so you explore more of the map and see new sights).

Control-wise, this game also plays extremely well. At first, my time with the controls was chaotic. I've been using a 360 controller to play, and I tried to mess with too much at once, and ended up getting stuck in parking lots because I couldn't figure out how to reverse (ha). If you want to use a controller, I'd suggest not changing the controls from the standard they pick for you at first. Drive around a bit before you decide to change anything.

Moving on, as you make money doing jobs using another company's truck, the bank will eventually contact you and let you know they're offering you a loan. It's enough to buy your first truck, but you'll have to be diligent in making sure you make enough money each day to make your loan payments. With your own truck, you're free to explore the map without a time limit (though you do pay for gas!), finding new truck dealers, farms/factories/cargo drop offs, recruitment agencies, and even future garages that you can buy to expand your grasp in the truck business industry across Europe. Once you work hard at that, the bank will increase your credit limit--allowing you to upgrade your garage if you wish, allowing you to buy additional trucks and hire drivers for you.

Driving simulation now gives way to business management, and this is pure enjoyment of the genre here. You have a number of garages you can obtain later on in the game once you have enough money, but at first, you'll just be buying another truck and assigning it to the additional space in your garage, where you can hire a driver to use. You can use any recruitment agency you've found to hire a driver, and from there you can hire them based on their skills and rating. Not only do they also level up, you can choose how you want them to work. For example, I chose to have my first hired driver focus on long distance jobs, since I myself was focused on shorter jobs that dealt with fragile or valuable cargo. Your hired drivers will also improve their rating over time, as they constantly are driving and working to improve their skills, though you have the authority to fire them if you so wish.

Last but not least--part of the charm in this game is just driving. It felt great to be driving a truck pulling 16 tons of cargo down the highways of Europe, discovering new cities and fulfilling contracts. I knew that with each job I completed, I was a tiny bit closer to paying off my loans, proving my worth in the industry, and making enough for that next truck or next upgrade. Also, the game has a radio feature, which lets you listen to live streams of a great selection of European radio stations--yes, real stations in real time while driving in a Euro truck simulation--and this is awesome. Last night while playing this game, I was driving my truck to a city I'd never seen before, pulling tons of cargo in the dead of night. Only once in a while would another car drive by because of the time, so I was mostly alone on the road. The radio station was playing some older American rock hits between commercials in another language. I was able to zone out. It was simply beautiful to just drive alone on a highway at night, listening to classic rock. I've never played a game that makes you feel so relaxed, so in awe of everyday things...and I've played thousands upon thousands of games. This game does it right.

I can't really say this game surprised me--based on the list of positive reviews, this game is a hit with many. But to think a game named Euro Truck Simulator 2 could be one of those games where you're watching the time get later and later and you think to yourself, Just one more

Unbelievable Truck Simulator! [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]

I started my truck driver life in a couple of minutes... In the first road stop, I watched to my left and then to my right for the street to be empty, then passed! No accidents! Then I spent the other 10 minutes trying to park that enormous truck without luck!

I got my second assignment, the real one... I had to try to avoid the other cars, I had to slow down on curves, I had to take curves with an eye on my back! reviewText:
I haven't been playing this game for very long, but I am really enjoying it so far and can definitely see many more hours ahead of me soon. ETS2 is a very relaxing, enjoyable, challenging and therapeutic game with so much to do and so many things to achieve. The concept is incredibly simple but as an actual game it works so well, it is difficult to explain why it's so fun, but just is!

You start off as a cargo truck driver for hire, doing small or large jobs for money so that you can form your own business with your own fully customisable trucks in a beautiful realistic environment. The cities and routes are not 100% accurate and not as long (that would be ridiculous) but it doesn't matter. There is still hundreds upon hundreds of hours of game play on offer and fantastic scenery all around the developers vision of Europe in this amazing simulator.

This time last year, I would have said that I do not understand how a truck simulator could be any fun as ever since I was a child I have questioned the fun factor of simulation games, but I am so glad that I spent £7.50 for the collection (ETS, ETS2, Bus Driver, Trucks and Trailers, Scania Truck Driving Simulator and plenty of DLC for ETS2), an absolutely amazing bargain.  Some of the best money I have ever spent and I have only played the one game of the collection so far!

ETS2 is worth every penny, so if you see it even cheaper than it's full retail price pick it up and you won't regret it. For the sake of £3.75, you should just buy it anyway!

reviewText:
Driving a truck can be as engaging and fun as any other game out there, you just need to give it a chance first. A game where the basic concept is simple, you drive your truck from point a to point b, get rewarded with money and continue on with future jobs, but where other simulators fail to hook the player, Euro Truck Simulator 2 manages to do the job right.

This is not your average driving a truck simulator, in it you actually get to upgrade your vehicle, upgrade your character, level up, customize almost anything on your truck and even start your own company where you can hire other people to drive your trucks and make money for you. But hey, if you don't feel like doing any of that, there's always random jobs up on the job board from people that have a truck and need you to do a delivery, after you finish the job you return the truck and get your money, nothing more and nothing less, so this way I find it extremely easy to get into and just enjoy.

Driving for great distances can sometimes be associated with boring" which is not the case at all here. I find this to be the most relaxing game I have ever experienced
