reviewText:
I love this game.

- TL;DR - Buy the game and be a happy trucker. (Edit)

This game offers a uniqe truck experience, not the like the otherones, in ETS2 you can freeroam once you've bought your own truck. I've played my own bit, and if you -really- want to play this game alot, I suggest you to invest in a steeringwheel controller, as it's more fun and realistic.

Once you've started getting into the game, you don't want to stop playing it, mainly because you have your own company. As you play, your company will grow if you want it to, the game offers a uniqe trucking company simulator at the price of €20, you'll get both a trucking- and company simulator.

The gameplay of ETS2 is fun, with the ''Going east!'' DLC you get a bit better roads, more challenging and more road interaction, i.e roadworks.

Overall I'd rate this game a solid 9/10
- Gameplay 7/10
- Interactions 8/10
- Player system 10/10
- Map 9.5/10

reviewText:
It takes every ounce of your energy to not take this game at face value, but is imperative to this sublime simulator that you don't.  Yes, it is a game about driving trucks.  Yes, the hauls get to be long distance.  If you're looking for something that keeps you on the edge of your seat, with non-stop action, this is not your game.

However, if you're looking for one of the most true to life, masterfully done, in-depth simulator you've ever sunk your teeth into, you've come to the right place.

I remember joking with my buddies LOL who wants to drive truck".  Then a few weeks later

hoursPlayed: ETS2 has a demo.  I'll give it a shot

and get to haulin'.  ETS2 gets a 4/5.

reviewText:
I'm driving my truck at night down a windy road near the Alps when I suddenly see brakelights in front of me. I hit my own brakes, and my 4T load begins to shift, making my entire truck slide down the road towards the car I am desperately trying to avoid. I hit the gas, and manage to avoid both the car and the hangrail just in time for me to continue.
An hour later I arrive at my destination with zero damage, and park the truck backwards.
Another bonus, and another cash influx to pay of my bank loan. Hopefully soon I'll be out of debt, and can begin saving for a larger garage and second truck.

ETS2 is an extremely addicting truck simulator. I love just driving my cargo from England to Poland, from Holland to Italy, and back... it can be so relaxing that sometimes, I get in situations like the above. Making it out of a near crash caused by your own inattention is such a satisfying feeling.

reviewText: Surprisingly fun game! I'm playing for about seven months now and still not bored. You can make it has hard or easy as you want to, just by turning on or off some of the simulation aspects. It can be a very relaxing game to play. Just driving about, enjoying the beautiful scenery and listening to your music in the background. I often play it at the end of the day, just to cool down from work and all the daily worries. The game is also constantly being updated with new features and improvements. (A big AI update is coming too) The game itself is already great but there are tons of great mods available, wich make it even better. New trucks, trailers, maps, you name it. A steering wheel is recommended but certainly not necessary. You can play it with controller or keyboard too. Using a good steering wheel though is a totally different and greatly improved experience. If you have the proper hardware, this game can look absolutely gorgeous for a sim game. So... highly recommended. Happy trucking :)

reviewText: At first you will buy this to screw around. Then you do jobs to pay off your crippling debt. Then you start to do jobs for real. Then you make serious cash. Then you buy your own truck. Then you take out loans. Then you hire drivers. Soon you'll be hooked in, days have gone by, weeks, even. By now you've toured the whole of central Europe. Switzerland, France, Germany, and Great Britain are off your bucket list. Weeks, days, years, millenia later, your company is on autopilot. You have nothing to do anymore, bossman. So congratulations, you've won Euro Truck Simulator 2 and successfully become the Ron Cadillac of the European truck driving industry.\n\n11/10

reviewText:
Score: 8.5/10
This game is a gem which unfortunately has to tumble through the simulation genre with the rest of the ordinary boring rocks. Many other simulation games out there give the genre a bad name, but this game is truly incredible not only to the genre of simulation but to gaming as a whole.

Tl;dr
This relaxing, addictive game is for anybody. Simulator enthusiasts. Gamers. Children. Adults. Men. Women. Anyone. It's potentially captivating to such a wide range of an audience, that it's definitely worth downloading the demo to see if you like the flesh of the game. And if (when) you do like it, you can buy the meat.

What is it?
Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game where you lead a trucking company, at first making money fairly slowly doing freelance jobs for random people (using their trucks) until you can afford your own truck. The quickjob part of the game shows you the flesh of what's going to come within the rest of the game, it lets you get to grips with the mechanics of driving the trucks in game, and gives you a general feel as to what you're going to be doing.

When you get your own truck, the real meat of the game starts to show as you can make much more money from jobs which can then be used to do a series of things:

Buy more trucks (♥♥♥♥ yeah).
Hire workers to drive your trucks for you and make you money (we talk about this next <3).
Pimp yo' truck.
Buy a big ♥♥♥ garage in every city in Europe and keep your freshly-pimped trucks in them.
The main things here are buying more trucks and hiring the workers. Once you've hired your first worker, you realise Actually
date: this is turning into a company
recommended: old turbo Joe himself is under my command in his fresh little pimp mobile. I'm gonna make the big bucks."\n\nAnd that's how it goes
hoursPlayed: you do more jobs
voteText: get more money
helpfulPercent: buy more trucks
votesHelpful: hire Turbo Joe and Rod Stewart to drive your trucks
votesTotal: and voila
votesFunny: you have an exponentially growing company.\n\nThere is also a leveling system in the game
commentsCount: which gives you a skill point for each level. This leveling system allows your to get longer distance jobs
column16: hold fragile cargos
column17: get bonuses for driving economically
column18: getting to your destination earlier bonuses
column19: and other things. The leveling system is good
column20: but it doesn't add much to the content
column21:
just allows you to make more money for each individual job.

That doesn't seem like a lot content?
Okay
column22:
so you don't want to splash the twenty buckaroos on Turbo Joe trucker Sim 2 because you're worried you won't find enjoyment in the game?

Here's what I'd suggest.

Play the demo for an hour or two

column25: the meat of the game is going to add to the experience tenfold as it gives you big goals to go towards
column26:
but doesn't make them impossible to get.

How does this game make you feel inside?
I feel like the sexiest thing on earth when I haul that big load straight into the delivery point. And you will too (if you don't think you will
column27: try that god damned demo).\n\nSeriously though

column29: just enough to stay in your lane and to know when to turn off. The game proposes a constant low level difficulty
column30: meaning that it's easy to play and you can be great at it as soon as you start
column31: but this constant low level difficulty means that you've got to balance between relaxing and fully enjoying the game and keeping your eyes on the road. In my opinion they've done a really good job with this.\n\nI currently find myself coming home and playing this over WoW
column32: which tells me the devs have done a really good job at giving the game a pull factor
column33:
making you want to come back to it time and time again.

Any mods worth getting
The Euro Truck Simulator 2 Multiplayer mod makes the game a different experience

reviewText:
I am a trucker. I have been driving trucks and hauling trailers since I was 18. I even have certificate of profession to show for as a trucker. To put it short, I know trucks. I have driven them for all my time under the hardest conditions - because I have driven in western and northern Norway. These roads are pure hell during the winter - and the winter is LONG here. Imagine blizzards, short periods of daylight, narrow roads twisting around mountains and over bridges to reach that one ferry that only crosses 7 times a day. Stryn Mountain. Hamarøya. Korg Mountain. Iceroad Truckers can go wet their beds.

I am a trucker. After 9 hours on the road, I have often sat down in my Volvo or Scania or DAF or whatever office I would be driving at that time, to play Euro Trucker 1 and 2. Pretty strange. One should believe that after so many years, I would have had trucks and diesel too far up my troath - but no. I like these games. Although very simple and not that demanding as it can be in real life, they are fun, relaxing and addictive. It also helps that there is a HUGE community providing a high level of addons for this game.

Can't wait for the Scandinavian addon. Let's see how much more demanding they can make it.

reviewText:
Something about this game is addictive... it's indescribable...
No one will ever figure out why ...but it's amazing.

The graphics are fantastic, even on medium to low settings, and it won't kill your gpu either. The driving mechanics are great. The AI can be stupid at times, but it somehow adds to the charm of this game. The aspect of customizing your truck keeps you working to get the extra cash you need to upgrade your engine or put on that new coat of paint or even add some lights or horns.
With any good sim, certain aspects of the game can be changed to accomadate your play style, like turning off the sleep simulation or the speed limiter (but sadly traffic fines cannot).

While the vinalla game gets dull after a couple hours, the moddability adds hours upon hours of awesome. There are truck mods, trailer mods (my favorite), and even map mods to freshen the game up.

The one problem you might face with this game is finding the control style that's right for you. Some people like it, but I would strongly caution you to NOT use the keyboard or mouse/keyboard control schemes. The second option is better if you're on a budget, but it's still not great. If you want to get a great experience out of this game, buy a Xbox controller (which I'm stuck with at the moment) or get a racing wheel (strongly reccomended); it will make the game infinitely better.

The game's not for everyone, but I suggest you give it a try; you might like it (I sure do)
9/10

reviewText: For the past few years, the JRPG genre has been seeing a dry spell, as many titles have sacrificed interesting characters and plot for fancy graphics and allowing several characters to fall into common and unwanted tropes. Additionally, many companies no longer localize their titles for the U.S. and Europe due to their belief that their games will not sell well enough in the other countries. For example, Square Enix's Final Fantasy series began as a JRPG true to its roots, instantly becoming a cult classic. In recent titles, however, there has been an influx of cinematics and high fidelity graphics, all of which are seemingly the trade-off for the qualities lost. Many things that defined the genre and made the stories and gameplay interesting were lost as JRPGs got more and more caught up in the new and fresh" looks and styles in more modern titles.\nDespite the apparent loss in quality in JRPGs
date: the genre is very much alive and well! Euro Truck Simulator 2 came out only a year ago
recommended: and yet it is proving itself to be a JRPG true to its elements. The story progression feels real and well-paced. The characters feel very human and never fall into any of the stereotypical roles filled by JRPG characters ( i.e. the edgy one
hoursPlayed: the tsundere one
voteText: the emotionless one
helpfulPercent: etc etc). This is in part due to the fantastic voice acting by great signature voices such as Nolan North
votesHelpful: Troy Baker
votesTotal: and Danny Devito. I praise this
votesFunny: yet I would go as far to say that the game is just as good without any voice acting
commentsCount: but I digress. The gameplay in Euro Truck Simulator 2 blows every AAA title in recent years out of the water. So many puzzles and combat mechanics in the game are well refined and done so with the story in mind.\nOverall
column16: I could not recommend this game any more to any true die hard fan of the JRPG genre
column17: or someone new to the genre. Everything from plot
column18: to combat
column19: and to graphics do not fail to impress me. This is definitely my game of the year
column20: the decade
column21: and maybe even the century. Kudos to you
column22: SCS software
column23: you Gods among men.\n3/10"

reviewText:
To keep this review short, here is a brief list of pro's and con's.

Pro's:
-Great looking vehicle models
-Road sense plays a big part in this game
-A massive, fully explorable map (and every single road, city or bridge have accurate signs)
-Limitless combianations of truck parts and paint jobs which are all under your control
-Smooth, easy interface, if you are new to simulators its easy to get started in this game
-Multiplayer mod. Need I say more?

Con's:
-The map is massive, but while driving through England or france there are'nt any landmarks. This isnt too bad if you just enjoy the core gameplay (driving) but it can make it a little repetitive
-Levelling up can take a while

You drive on Europe (except Portugal, Spain and south France) with a truck delivering some cargos. You start earning money, build your company and soon you should be rich, when you have a lot of workers with you.

The traffic on the game it's very realistic. Sometimes you will crash into the traffic and not even your fault. Good landscapes and the rain it's also a nice addition.

If you buy the DLC Going East you will unlock more map to righ side (Hungary for example is unlocked).

The only problem is the music. You need to play with music on or you will be tired of the game.

For me it's 8/10

reviewText: A nice relaxing truck driving sim.  Some might dismiss it as something ridiculously boring, but it's more than you think.  It's well made by a small Czech developer with years of experience in the trucking sim, so this is top tier in the simulator genre. reviewText:
Euro Truck Simulator is one of the greatest, if not the greatest open-world simulator games on the market right now. At the time of this review, the Steam Holidays Sale is currently going on and the price is 85% normal, which is twenty-five USD.

Pros:
+Beautiful game, and doesn't really bog your game down.

+Every trip is an adventure, and with the ability to have the radio, it makes every single trip entertaining. You can also impliment your own songs and play them from the radio as you venture into the wild blue yonder!

+Start your own company, and rise to greatness as one of the best truck companies in Europe.

+The game is very realistic, where you use your driving wits to get you through each trip.

+Trafic acts realisticly, where cars will go into the other lane to get ahead of you, people will honk at you for being to slow or not going at a green light, etc etc etc.

+Explore parts of Austria, Germany, the UK, France and many more countries! With the DLC, Heading East, you can explore even more!

+Modding support!

Cons:
-The game is quite expensive, and you have to play a bit to get your money's worth.

-There are a lot of things to remember, but if you're like me and like that, then you're fine.

-You  must  set aside some time every day or so to play this game to get anywhere in it.

All in all, I definately recommend this to anyone who likes roleplay, exploring Europe, or just like semi's. Pick it up on a sale and play to your heart's content.

9.48/10.

reviewText:
Let me paint you a picture:

Got done with classes for the day and you just want to unwind, but you don't want to pickup a shooter or play Binding of Isaac for the 67,000th time. You want just want to relax with something that doesn't involve death or killing for once.

So you map ETS2 to your DualShock 4 (or other respective controller) and boot that puppy up. Throw on Liverpool FM or Nostalgia FM and just unwind and drive your haul across Europe on the open road taking in the beautiful scenery and peaceful landscape while your favorite music plays in your ear.

Add to that the multiplayer mod and you've now got a convoy of your friends, which all mocked you playing the game days ago, but are now doing their fourth haul in a row to level up just one more time while listening to the BBC News station and weighing the chances of their driver falling asleep at the wheel or their truck running out of gas before reaching their 14 hour destination across Europe.

You see other trucks on the road in the multiplayer mod and you honk hello!" at them and they honk "hello!" back at you and you go on your way. Safe travels
date: friend! You think to yourself as you continue your midnight haul to Hamburg with your trailer full of ice cream and classic rock playing out your radio.\n\nEuro Truck Simulator 2: It's just so comfy!"

reviewText:
I don't know why I find this game so enjoyable, I don't even care about the trucks in the real world.

This game doesn't cut corners about the scenery which is rich and ever-changing as you drive around the Europe, there is always something new to see. The game as a whole is very well produced and I haven't encountered any obvious bugs. I'd say this is high quality stuff all-around.

Even though I already have over 20 hours of the game time (at the moment of writing this review), I haven't even touched the garages feature not hired any drivers for my truck company yet (didn't even upgrade all my skills yet). All I did so far was bought my own truck (you don't have your own truck at the beginning) and upgraded the engine and transmission with money I made from cargo deliveries. I'm taking my time to enjoy it and it's not getting boring, in fact just looking at the Steam store screenshots makes me eager to play more.

Driving the truck feels very satisfying with Xbox 360 controller for PC and the game is very generous with force feedback (and I'm not talking about raw intensity but details, you'll feel virtually everything).

Note that for force feedback to work with Xbox 360 controller, you may need to install the additional translation-driver because newer versions of Windows no longer fully support DirectInput which this game uses. See Steam forums for more info (that's where I found the Force Feedback Driver for XInput" by Masahiko Morii which works great on Windows 8.1 for me).

Also worth noting
date: this game is great to play while listening to the talk-podcasts or audio books. The game is relaxing and non-interfering in nature. As one of the reviews here say

reviewText:
This game is amazing. But calling it a game would be too low for this masterpiece. Euro Truck Simulator 2 can run on a dinosaur pc, intel graphics, or you can have it devour all the power your PC can push, and it LOOKS AMAZING! It's a great way to wind down after a long day at class or work.

While it is possible to play with the keyboard, I reccommend at least using a controller, but the best experisnce is with a 900 degree turn radius steering wheel. If you have force-feedback on it, it will allow you too feel the truck as you start driving: you can feel the road under the tires, and occassionally hit a rumble strip.

You can't go wrong, it is an amazing experience, and I reccomend it to anyone who loves to drive, race, or likes open-world driving.

reviewText: This game is far more fun than it should be.  It's relaxing, driving around in your big rig to music from the many online radio stations from around the world.  It's challenging, trying to park your rig to earn that extra money and XP.  It's got a very nice progression system, earning experience to improve your skills.  Customizing your trucks with better equipment and paint styles.  It's deep, in that you can buy your own garages, hire drivers, buy trucks for them to drive and grow your business.  It's beautiful, the scenery is sometimes breathtaking as you drive across farming fields, through cities, over mountain roads, through the rain and fog and night time.  It's one of my favorite games of the year, and although I find that surprising to say out loud, it honestly is.  It's like the Elite or Privateer of driving simulation games.  Very much recommended if you want a relaxing but fun and challenging driving game.

reviewText: At first, this game looked ridiculously boring and I didn't even see a point in trying it. Well, after giving it a shot with an open mind, I stand corrected. This is one of the most fun games I've played in the past 5 years, and probably one of the best driving games I've played in my life. It proves that a game doesn't need to be a racing game, to provide an enjoyable driving experience. Match this with the beautiful scenery (that changes frequently enough to keep things interesting) and you have a great game. It won't appeal to everyone, but if you enjoy driving and have always had an interest in 18 wheelers, then I would suggest giving this game a shot. I know I'm glad I did.

reviewText: A game most would criticize initially upon reading about it for it's simplicity and it's ability to hold someone's attention for long enough. Anyone who has played the game before however, knows this isn't the case. Euro Truck Simulator 2 brings more to the genre then the conventional simulation game. They really take the simple idea behind the game and drive it home. No pun intended.\nThe game does a great job with the progression speed, it's slow, but not slow to the point where you find yourself bored. You gain skills over time permitting you to haul different cargo, drive longer distances, and more.\nAfter my initial skepticism, the game has since grown into one of my favorite games. No other game can quite capture the relaxing feel you have when playing ETS 2. A game where you can turn on some music and just drive to most any of Europe's most prominent cities.

reviewText: I didn't expect to love this game as much as I do. I bought it on a lark during a Steam sale for under $3. I've plowed about 70 hours into it over the last few months, playing almost every night. There's something very peaceful about this driving game -- almost completely the opposite of the average racing game. It's about driving carefully, obeying traffic rules, and slowly building your truck empire. The graphics are lovely - you'll send a lot of time driving around, just looking at the scenery and the wonderful little touches that make the in-game locations look like their real-world counterparts. My favorite part of the whole game is the ability to listen to (European) radio stations while you're driving. I grew up in Belgium and now live on the West Coast of the US; as a result, I can now listen to the Belgian morning radio shows as I drive around at night. You may be skeptical about a truck sim game -- I was -- but put plain and simple, this is some of the most fun I've had playing a PC game in years. Recommended!
